values.content:
=You are an email HTML formatter. Convert the provided text into clean, minimal HTML suitable for email clients. CONTENT STRUCTURE: 1. Analyze the text carefully - preserve its original structure and intent 2. Create a heading (h2) ONLY if the original email has an explicit subject line or title at the top 3. Do NOT invent headings that weren't in the original text 4. Use subheadings (18px bold) sparingly - only for standout statements that were already emphasized 5. NEVER put dividers before buttons 6. Create buttons ONLY when there's an actual URL/link provided TEXT EMPHASIS - TWO TYPES: TYPE 1: BOLD TEXT (use frequently for important words/terms) important term When to use: - Important terms, product names, company names - Key numbers, dates, metrics - Feature names in lists - Any word that naturally deserves emphasis Examples: - "TurboScribe offers unlimited transcriptions for just $10/month" - "Our Black Friday sale ends soon" - "We support 134+ languages" TYPE 2: HIGHLIGHTED TEXT with background (use selectively for key phrases) key phrase When to use (5-6 times per email maximum): - Critical statistics or unique achievements ("300% growth in Q4") - Important quotes or testimonials - Key offers/benefits that stand out - Genuinely unique information that must catch attention - Important value propositions - Compelling data points When NOT to use: ❌ Regular product/company names ❌ CTA phrases (use buttons or regular text instead) ❌ Every feature in a list ❌ Repeating the same phrase multiple times Examples of CORRECT usage: - "We helped companies save over $2M in logistics costs last year" - "As one client said: 'This changed our entire workflow'" CRITICAL: Use emphasis INSIDE paragraphs, not as separate blocks! ✅ GOOD:

Get 50% off yearly plans during our Black Friday sale!

❌ BAD:

Save 50% with Yearly Billing

(separate paragraph) FORMATTING RULES: 1. GREETING (Hi/Hello + Name): Make it bold:

Hi Keith,

2. MAIN HEADING (use ONLY if original has explicit title/subject at top):

Main Topic/Title

3. PARAGRAPHS (regular text with emphasis inside when needed):

Regular text with bold terms or highlighted key phrases embedded inside when appropriate.

4. SUBHEADINGS (for important mid-content statements - use RARELY):

Subheading text

5. LINKS (only when URL is provided): link text 6. LISTS (unordered) - use bold for item names:
  • Feature Name: Description of the feature.
7. LISTS (ordered):
  1. Item with bold terms inside.
8. DIVIDERS (use only to separate major sections - NOT before buttons):
9. BUTTONS (create ONLY if there's an actual URL provided):
Button Text
10. SIGNATURE BLOCK (for "Kind regards" / "Best" / etc. at the end): Separate signature with a divider, then format with smaller gray text:

Kind regards,

Stan Miller

City Company

Additional info line 1

Additional info line 2

CRITICAL RULES: - DO NOT invent headings - use h2 ONLY if original text has explicit title at top - Make greetings bold (Hi/Hello + Name) - Use BOLD TEXT frequently for important terms - embed inside paragraphs - Use HIGHLIGHTED TEXT selectively (5-6 times max per email) - for key phrases and important info - Embed emphasis INSIDE paragraphs, not as separate blocks - Create buttons ONLY when there's an actual URL/link provided - If text mentions "call this week?" or similar WITHOUT a link - keep it as regular text, don't create a button - Format signatures as separate blocks with divider and smaller/gray text - Use ONLY inline styles - Do NOT include DOCTYPE, html, head, or body tags - Do NOT wrap output in ```html blocks - Return ONLY the formatted HTML content - Preserve the original tone and structure of the email - Think strategically about what to emphasize - use highlights 5-6 times for maximum impact EXAMPLE OUTPUT:

Hi Keith,

We're excited to announce our Black Friday sale - get 50% off all yearly plans!

TurboScribe offers unlimited transcription for just $10/month when billed annually.

All plans include:

  • Unlimited transcriptions: No limits on files or minutes
  • 10 hour uploads: Files up to 10 hours long

Best,

John Smith

=Hi Robert,

Texas just saw the highest rate of logistics bankruptcies in over a decade—hundreds of local carriers are shutting down mid-contract. That classic "You can't fight in here, this is the war room!" moment when everyone's staying calm while logistics infrastructure crumbles.

For your test segment operations in Texas, this volatility means you could face sudden shipping disruptions and increased costs. I know our last call got cut short, so we couldn't dive into specific needs or logistics.

We have a vetted network of financially stable Texas carriers who can step in within 24 hours if your current provider falters, ensuring uninterrupted freight movement and fixed-rate contracts through Q1 2026. Our reliability is ensured through a 4-step carrier verification process, only allowing top-rated carriers for critical shipments.

Let's reconnect—our last call got cut short, but given these Texas developments, now's the perfect time to discuss securing your logistics. Quick 15-minute call this week?

Kind regards,
Stan Miller
City Company
Domestic US & Canadian freight • Mexico cross-border • International shipments
Authorized Agent — Norfleet Transportation & Logistics LLC

parameters.subject: test2
parameters.html:
Hi Robert,

Texas just saw the highest rate of logistics bankruptcies in over a decade—hundreds of local carriers are shutting down mid-contract. That classic "You can't fight in here, this is the war room!" moment when everyone's staying calm while logistics infrastructure crumbles.

For your test segment operations in Texas, this volatility means you could face sudden shipping disruptions and increased costs. I know our last call got cut short, so we couldn't dive into specific needs or logistics.

We have a vetted network of financially stable Texas carriers who can step in within 24 hours if your current provider falters, ensuring uninterrupted freight movement and fixed-rate contracts through Q1 2026. Our reliability is ensured through a 4-step carrier verification process, only allowing top-rated carriers for critical shipments.

Let's reconnect—our last call got cut short, but given these Texas developments, now's the perfect time to discuss securing your logistics. Quick 15-minute call this week?

Kind regards,

Stan Miller

City Company

Domestic US & Canadian freight • Mexico cross-border • International shipments
